Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Algebraic Tools for Coding, Complexity and Combinatorics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops algebraic tools for applications in computational complexity, coding theory and incidence geometry. These application domains describe three areas within the fields of computer science, electrical and mathematics driven by very distinct motivations. Computational complexity aims to understand the fundamental limits of algorithms. Coding theory aims to study methods that can protect digital information from errors that inevitably creep in to every storage medium or communication channel. Incidence geometry studies combinatorial properties, such as size of dimension, of points in space that satisfy nice geometric properties. Despite the vast difference in scope, many central results in the three areas have come about by an understanding of basic algebraic properties of functions. This project aims to develop this basic understanding further to enable many more of such applications, and to bring these areas together. Some central algebraic properties that are being explored in this project include (1) highly-efficient randomized methods to test if a multivariate function is essentially a low-degree polynomial, (2) study of how symmetries of algebraic properties enable highly-efficient tests, and (3) use of higher-order derivatives in the study of incidence geometry.

The project involves the mentoring and education of junior researchers (Ph.D. candidates) who intend to pursue their own careers in research, especially those interested in interdisciplinary studies within mathematics, electrical engineering and computer science. The education component of this project will develop courses and material of use in this interdisciplinary research project, and thus also help contribute to its broad impact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This goal of this project develop was to develop algebraic tools for applications in computational complexity, coding theory and geometry. These application domains describe three areas within the fields of computer science, electrical engineering and mathematics driven by very distinct motivations. Computational complexity aims to understand the fundamental limits of algorithms. Coding theory aims to study methods that can protect digital information from errors that inevitably creep in to every storage medium or communication channel. Geometry aims to understand and exploit the behavior of objects in space to infer non-trivial consequences and obstructions. 

The main results obtained in this project were: (1) New algorithms and analyses for testing algebraic properties under very weak assumptions.  Whereas previous works could only test the family of low-degree polynomials over entire vector spaces, the new works allow testing using only the symmetries of the property being tested, and do not require the function to be defined over the entire space. (2) Extension of the study of polynomials beyond the finite field setting to the setting of reals: Here, our works give novel dimension reduction techniques to reduce the study of polynomials in a large number of variables to the study of small-variate polynomials. (3) Initiation of the complexity of measuring tensored properties and in particular a decidability result for measuring the maximum correlation obtainable from random bits generated from correlated sources of randomness.  (4) Study of arithmetic circuit complexity of basic operations.

Intellectual Merit: The broad scope of the project led to many unexpected directions of progress linking algebra, property testing, symmetries, and communication. Several directions of progress (such as those in testing properties based on symmetries) were planned activities, whereas other directions such as the dimension reduction for polynomials over the reals, and study of communication complexity using symmetries of the function being computed are unexpected new directions. We expect that many of the new directions will inspire further research in the years to come.


Broader Impact: Six Ph.D. students, including one woman, were supported by this award. Three of these have graduated and have joined the industry in research level positions. Additionally, three postdocs were supported by this award, one of whom has gone on to an industrial position, while the other two are continuing as postdocs and likely to continue to faculty positions.
